sourceDesc.bibl: Birth Curb Crusader Spends Day in IslesHonolulu Star Bulletin04/07/1954

docBody.head: Birth Curb Crusader Spends Day in Isles

div.p: After a 50-year crusade, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, now 71, still vigorously believes the answer to the world's economic problems lies in birth control.
She thinks Hawaii should pay heed, too.

Mrs. Sanger stopped ion Honolulu today as a guest of the Watumull Foundation. She is en route back to Japan for another birth control meeting, and is making the trip even though she had "to scrape the bottom of the barrel" to finance it.
"Keep birth control out of politics and religion," she said today. "Be guided by your scientists and economists."

div.head: LESS DANGER SIGNS
div.p: She said the economic reports she has seen on Hawaii indicate it faces the danger of having more people than its industries can support in the years to come.
Mrs. Sanger spent today at the SurfRider Hotel and leaves tonight by Japan Air Lines.

While in Japan she will confer with Japanese officials on an April, 1955 International Planned Parenthood Federation scheduled there. "Some new methods of birth control will be disclosed at that time," she said.

div.head: MUCH OPPOSITION
div.p: Mrs. Sanger said "we haven't won yet... subtle and brutal forces" continue to work against the program.
